summary: This is a Bureau of Prisons Psychological Reconstruction Report on the death by suicide of inmate Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Complex (MCC) New York on August 10, 2019. The report details Epstein's incarceration history, mental health assessments, antecedent circumstances, and provides numerous findings and recommendations regarding institutional procedures, staffing, and documentation errors that contributed to the incident.

keyFacts: The report is an interim psychological reconstruction due to an inability to gather all necessary data, including the lack of a video (confiscated by the FBI) and formal interviews to avoid interfering with pending DOJ investigations.
Epstein was found dead in his single-occupancy SHU cell on August 10, 2019, despite a prior suicide attempt/gesture on July 23, 2019, and recommendations for him to be double-celled.

Significant procedural failures are documented, including failure to complete proper 30-minute rounds, inaccurate SENTRY cell assignments, documentation errors in medical and psychology records, and log book irregularities.
On August 9, 2019, the day before his death, approximately 2,000 pages of court documents containing graphic allegations against Epstein were unsealed, further eroding his status.
The report concludes that factors contributing to Epstein's suicide likely included the loss of his status, lack of significant interpersonal connections, and the prospect of life in prison.
